body.p:
Rev S. Morais
My dear Sir

I am just in the receipt of your welcome and esteemed
favor of the 8th and read the same with a great deal of interest and attention.
Next week I must begin to prepare for the laborious work of the [Hebrew] and lest I may
not have the time before [Hebrew] to reply, I prefer doing so at once, whilst your excel-
lent words are still fresh in my mind. Permit me [Hebrew]

Pardon me for saying that I do not altogether agree with you in your comparison
between the Talmudists of the Spanish Italian School and those of the German-Po-
lish. If that comparison could be entertained it would be the key to the idiosyn-
crasies of reform. You are right in contending that the Talmudists of your school
did not despise profane learning, but the statement needs qualification. Joseph
Kolen and Juda Mentz[?] belonged to the Italian school; their bitterness to any
and the slightest innovation exceeds the rigor of the Polish school. Kabbalism,
which I still abhor, originated in Spain and was protected and nourished
in Italy before it ever touched Poland; Zabbatai Zebi was recommended by
Italians to the congregations of the north and west, and the worst act of
intolerance on record, the [Hebrew] against Ben Uziel and Spinoza is Sephardic.
In spite of all this, I have been forcibly struck with your remarks, which
has set me thinking, and I do concede, that the profane knowledge of
your school protects the fences of conservatism, whilst the ignorance of
its Polish Lamdonim, if once corrected, leads to Kohlerism, to tilulate[?] the
opinions of my otherwise dear and excellent friend. And, on the other hand,
your comparison proves that you are not in line with the Polish
German orthodox. I can agree with you—but I cannot argue with them.

I am glad you commend my article. It was written as a sort of compro-
mise. I had intended a series of ten articles entitled "Between the] two fires,"
in which I intended to prove that neither Kohler's or Kohut's position were
tenable in America, or in other words, that both "German reform" and "Mos-
aic-Talmudical Judaism" were a failure so far as this country is
concerned. I underlined my title " a plea for as[?]] an intelligent conser-
vatism" and I smiled when, after seeing you use the same term, I thought
how I had hit the nail on the head. That term "intelligent conservatism"
is going to be the watchword of American Jews and [Hebrew] you will
live to see the revolution take place,only you must help along; and
you can do it. Pardon me, if I am to be frank, but I speak from the very
depths of [^] my heart, every pulsation of which beats for the honor and the
integrity of our holy religion—Your uncompromising position hampers
us younger men, though we understand and appreciate it. You can be
of such vast advantage in aiding us to remodel out convictions,
and just now is the time. We cannot follow Kohut, because he does
not know the people and the country. But we could follow you, or to
say, what would please you better, you could indicate the way to
conciliate "intelligent conservatism" with the opinions of most young
Rabbis in the United States. Years ago, when you wrote your excellent
and admirable articles on "essentials" in the Record, Rev Mr. Isaacs
[Hebrew] feel enthused to call a meeting of conservatives—you were then
reluctant. Now—as I indicate in that series of articles, which will
yet be published—the way to begin thinking of a reconciliation
is to compare opinions. It is strange that so many people think
ritual and [Hebrew] the only differences. The first thing would really
be a discussion on doctrines. Liberals have eliminated [Hebrew] and
[Hebrew] from their prayerbooks, which indicates that they discard
these fundamentals. Now, one believes in [Hebrew], the other in [Hebrew]
I] one believes in a [Hebrew] the other in [Hebrew] or even in [Hebrew].
One accepts the [Hebrew] to which even Kohut does no more sub-

scribe, the other takes Albo as a guide and so forth. Do you not think
that these differences have to be reconciled? As far as the [Hebrew] or
[Hebrew] is concerned, it is needless to point out that, when a reconci-
liation can be effected these person or things will be attended to, and at
any rate too much prominence is given to these matters. We always have
had [Hebrew] in that direction. As to the Sabbath—it is a problem, as much
to conservatives as to liberals. But don't think that a union of the
factions might accomplish something in that direction also?

I am, indeed, dreaming of an " intelligent conservatism" for I have rea-
lized that German reform is a complete failure. But you must concede
that Mosaic-Talmudism is not to be thought of. We cannot go against
[Hebrew] not against what would be unreasonable in our times.
I was telling an old orthodox Pole in New York of my day dreams,
and I told Dr. Kohler the same—they actually agreed! I am
dreaming that some day we will be able to reconstruct Judaism
upon a basis, like this for instance:

1.A uniform ritual, agreeable to orthodox and reform alike, containing
the historical prayers in Hebrew, and additions in English.

2. A Hymnbook—English--setting forth the doctrines of Israel,
the singing to be done—as in the good old Sephardic congrega-
tion in Amsterdam—by the entire congregation.

3. A revival of the individual consciousness, stimulated in the
Synagogue by reinstituting the [Hebrew], the notification of
births, marriages, deaths etc.

I have had long and earnest conversations with Kohler on these
subjects and he agrees with me. His last "splurt" is no criterion. Our
good Doctor is an idealist, easily moved, and at that critical mo-
ment he had to defend the fame of his late father-in-law Dr.
Einhorn, but Kohler is a conservative at the bottom of his heart
and can easily be won for the cause. You will easily perceive from
what I have written that my inclinations are in your direction.
We must have a [Hebrew] and reform does not offer it. But
on the other hand the Talmud offers no consolation in our
present trials. We have to fix our doctrines and to remodel our
minhagim. I concede that both can be done best and safest
from a Jewish historical standpoint, but it must be limited
to what our times actually require and what our reason
can accept. Is such a thing appropriate?

I hope I have not tried you with my crude remarks. I could do as
the balance, draw my salary and smoke my cigar without
care for the future. But thank God I have an earnest heart
and I am willing to learn, and I want to do my share towards
preserving the Thora. I know that my publication of the articles
mentioned will jeopardize my chance of Temple Emanuel, but
that will not deter me,-- only, it would not be a prudent to fight
a new cause single handed. If what I have written may induce
you to, at least, begin an investigation, whether for the sake
of many young ministers who think of you with respect and
reverence, whether you can consistently with your opinions upon
the subject of "intelligent conservatism" secede from your present
exclusive and uncompromising standpoint, there is hope that
the revival may come sooner than you expect. Let us, if possible
work together to ascertain a basis of common belief, in that
event the question of Minhagim and [Hebrew] will most likely
be easily adjusted.

Permit me to cordially reciprocate your good wishes for the new year.
May God spare you [Hebrew], and keep you in good health and
spirits to continue your work, Awaiting reply
